message_1:
Suppose two travelers have their bags mixed up at the airport. Each bag contains an identical set of 10 expensive gifts worth between $5 and $100. They agree to resolve the issue using the Traveler's Dilemma game theory model. Starting with $100, they will each simultaneously declare the value of the gifts in their bag. The traveler who declares the lowest amount will get $2 more than the amount declared, while the other traveler receives the amount they declared. If both travelers declare the same amount, they each receive that amount. 

What is the optimal amount to declare in this scenario?
message_2:
In the Traveler's Dilemma, the optimal strategy is to declare the lowest possible value. In this case, the lowest value is $5. Here's why:

If both travelers declare $100, they will each receive $100. However, if one traveler decides to declare $98, they will receive $100 ($98 + $2), while the other traveler will receive $98. This creates an incentive for each traveler to lower their declared value to gain the extra $2.

This process continues as each traveler has an incentive to lower their declared value to gain the extra $2. Eventually, the optimal strategy for both travelers is to declare the lowest possible value, which is $5 in this case. By declaring $5, the traveler who declares the lowest amount will get $7 ($5 + $2), while the other traveler receives $5. If both travelers declare $5, they each receive $5, which is the Nash equilibrium in this game.
